texts.definition: Discovering and deciding on a team strategy, often based upon using synergies.
markups: <style="Definition">Discovering and deciding on a team strategy, often based upon using synergies.</style>

Some games encourage or force players to work together. A part of working together is discovering how one's actions can be coordinated into supporting each other, and succeeding in finding such cases are examples of <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style>.

''Note: The use of 'team' in the name of this pattern refers to any type of cooperation between players rather than the more formalized cooperation that the pattern <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> describe.''

Quite naturally, <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> occurs in games where players need to cooperate. This is given in games where players either play in teams, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Soccer">Soccer</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bridge">Bridge</link></style>, or in those where players need to work together against the game system or game environment. Examples of games where the latter can promote <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Forbidden%20Island">Forbidden Island</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Yggdrasil">Yggdrasil</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> requires that players have other players to work together with and that they have a reason to find strategies. This means that the pattern relies on <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> and typically make use of more or less formalized structures for groups of players, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>. These can provide common goals which encourage common strategies or be ways for people that wish to cooperate to find like-minded. Providing external threats, either through other <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> or by <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style> gameplay, is another way to motivate players to find common strategies. In games where players have <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>, the goal of <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> can be to minimize losses within the player group or to evenly balance negative effects. <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> can also be encouraged in games where players have different <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> that have <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style> but where they still need to work as a <style="Link"><link="teams">Team</link></style>.

An exception to the rule that <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> needs multiple players is when <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> can be used. In this case human players need to figure out how the <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> function, or to which level they can negotiate over strategies.

The presences of <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> can help with <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> in games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> since in these cases the <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> can show the location of team members and players can to a certain extent find strategies solely on the knowledge of where the other players are.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> is a typically consequence of trying to reach <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style>. When strategies related to this are successfully identified, these can be perceived as <style="Link"><link="team-accomplishments">Team Accomplishments</link></style> and be <style="Link"><link="social-rewards">Social Rewards</link></style> for those active in the identification. Both identifying the strategy and being a part of that strategy can give a sense of <style="Link"><link="togetherness">Togetherness</link></style>. A typical result of <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> is the discovery or planned use of <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>.

The possibility of <style="CurrentLink">Team Strategy Identification</style> in games is likely to cause <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> (at least as long some players recognize this possibility).
